1. Solar Design Engineer: A solar design engineer designs and develops solar power generation systems. A bachelor's degree in mechanical or electrical engineering is required, and further training in renewable energy systems may be required.

2. Wind Turbine Technician: Wind turbine technicians install, maintain, and repair wind energy systems. An associate degree or technical training in wind energy technology is required.

3. Energy Efficiency Specialist: An energy efficiency specialist helps businesses and homeowners reduce their energy consumption by offering energy-saving advice and identifying areas that need improvement. A degree in environmental science or engineering is preferred.

4. Biomass Scientist: A biomass scientist researches new and more efficient ways to convert organic materials into biofuels. A degree in biochemistry or chemical engineering is preferred.

5. Geothermal Engineer: A geothermal engineer designs and develops systems that extract heat from the ground or water to generate energy. A degree in mechanical or civil engineering is required, and a background in geology may be helpful.

6. Hydropower Engineer: A hydropower engineer is responsible for designing, installing and maintaining hydropower systems. A degree in mechanical, civil or electrical engineering is required.

To get started pursuing any of these career paths in renewable energy, individuals can start by obtaining a relevant degree or certification in engineering, science, or technology. They can then seek internships or apprenticeships with companies in the renewable energy sector to gain real-world experience. Networking with professionals in the industry, attending conferences and events, and staying up-to-date with industry news and trends can also help individuals break into the field.
